newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkey prepares to draw up anti-inflation plan.
newsitem.headline: Turkey prepares to draw up anti-inflation plan.

text.p: Turkey has moved to draw up a plan to tackle high inflation, but as the Islamist-led coalition government came under severe strain economists stressed on Friday that political stability was essential for success.

A technical committee has been set up to decide on a medium-term stabilisation programme to tackle inflation currently running at around 80 per cent, said a senior economy official who declined to be named.
The official said the programme would aim to lower annual inflation to 10 percent over a period of three years.
"A technical committee including senior treasury, planning, central bank and finance ministry officials has been set up to prepare the programme," said the official.

"Every institution has prepared its own plan. We will come together and discuss them before reaching a final programme which will be able to win support from international financial bodies like the IMF," he added.
"The key question is whether the fall in inflation would be sharp or gradual. It will be determined after studies," he said.
Officials said the IMF asked Turkey to launch a medium-term programme to address the country's persistent economic problems earlier this month when a Fund team paid a consultation visit to Ankara.
State Minister Ufuk Soylemez, who flew to Washington on Friday to attend an IMF-World bank interim committee meeting, is expected to hold talks on the details of the programme with Fund officials.
Planning officials say Turkey might aim to raise $15 to $20 billion of privatisation revenue by end-1999 and to attain an annual growth rate of four to five percent under the programme.
"The programme may contain some measures to increase tax revenues and curb losses of pension funds and monetary tightening," an official said.
Turkey has been struggling with fiscal imbalances, high inflation, fuelled by budget deficits at over eight percent of gross national product, and widening foreign trade and current account gaps.
Economists question the chance of any programme, citing uncertainities over the future of Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan's coalition government.
"Look at the other examples across the world. Only those programmes implemented by strong governments had been successful," said a government economist.
Ercan Uygur, an economics professor at Ankara University, said Turkey could not stick by a firm programme for three years under present political and economic uncertainties.
Ankara had shelved a 20-month IMF stand-by programme in late 1995 over a government crisis which dragged the country to early elections.
"Three years is very long time in Turkey. I don't think that Turkey can implement a programme for such a period. It will be suspended on the half way," Uygur told Reuters.

Erbakan has been locked in a political war of attrition with the secularist armed forces which urged the government to implement tough measures against Islamist activism at a February meeting of the National Security Council (NSC).
The military members of the NSC are expected to increase demands on the reluctant government at a Saturday meeting to implement the measures.
Political concerns, sparked by the dispute, have been keeping financial and capital markets under pressure for two days.
"The political instability hampers the economy, exports, foreign capital inflow," said Mehmet Yildirim, head of Istanbul's Chamber of Trade, calling parliament to end the crisis soon.
